complex-numbers-fourier-problem-4: Now that we know the received signal is the sum of many elementary waves, we can finally isolate a specific one. The procedure is simple: we compare the signal with a complex rotation that spins exactly at the frequency we are interested in. If that frequency is truly present in the signal, the two rotations align and the result of the integration becomes large (i.e., close to the amplitude value). If it is not present, the rotations cancel each other out and the contribution vanishes. This way we extract only the desired component, separating it from everything else.

We want to verify whether frequency -5 is present in the signal and with what intensity. To do this, we multiply the signal by a complex rotation at frequency -5 and integrate over time.
